headline: Investigation of New York City Shelter Operator Grows
summary: New York City officials have expanded their investigation into a top nonprofit contractor that operates homeless shelters after discovering it has alleged undisclosed ties to a second for-profit company.

headline: Mexico Nears Deal to Resolve Pipeline Conflict
summary: The administration of Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has reached a preliminary agreement with four private energy companies to resolve a monthslong conflict over natural-gas-pipeline contracts.

headline: U.S. Companies on China: Breaking Up Is Hard
summary: American businesses, from technology startups to large corporations, say they cannot quickly upend their supply chains and stop doing business in China.

headline: Trump Aides Say He Isn’t Ordering U.S. Companies Out of China
summary: President Trump didn’t order U.S. companies to leave China and has no plans to invoke emergency powers to force them to relocate their operations, top administration officials said on Sunday, after a tumultuous week for trade negotiations.

headline: No Eggs, No Cream: New York’s Milkshake Gone Wrong Won’t Die
summary: Fans mix up variants on the fizzy concoction to save it; Nutella, whiskey

headline: Working Families Party Fights to Keep Fusion Voting
summary: The battle over New York’s fusion-voting system is playing out at a state commission overseeing campaign-finance-reform efforts, with the latest shots fired at a meeting last week.

headline: VMware Goes Beyond Dell Family Matters
summary: With its stock price being beaten down, software maker VMware will have to show it can juggle two complex acquisitions and while still managing some tricky Dell family relationships.

headline: Disney Stores Headed to 25 Target Locations
summary: Target and Disney have joined forces to open dedicated Disney Stores in about two dozen Target locations starting this fall, the latest example of a large retailer offering a specialty shop within its walls.

headline: Trump Says U.S. and Japan Have Reached Trade Deal in Principle
summary: President Trump said the U.S. and Japan had reached a trade deal “in principle” that would pave the way for more U.S. farm exports to Japan, while dropping the threat of U.S. tariffs on Japanese cars.

headline: Iran’s Foreign Minister Makes Unexpected Visit on Sidelines of G-7 Meeting
summary: Iran’s top diplomat made a surprise visit Sunday to the city hosting the Group of Seven summit, meeting with a delegation including President Emmanuel Macron as leaders grappled with how to defuse tensions and salvage a multination landmark nuclear deal after a U.S. pullout.

headline: Bernie’s Green Leap Forward
summary: Cost: $16 trillion. Fracking: banned. Oil CEOs: in jail.

headline: Qualcomm Gets a Reprieve
summary: The Ninth Circuit stays a bad ruling that would harm 5G innovation.

headline: Smearing Steven Menashi
summary: CNN and MSNBC distort another judicial nominee’s views.

headline: Economy Week Ahead: Durable Goods Orders, Personal Income
summary: In the week ahead, the U.S. Commerce Department releases data on durable goods orders and personal income. Canada issues GDP numbers, and China publishes factory numbers.

headline: What Influence Should Stakeholders Have?
summary: Were stakeholder momentum coming just from Sen. Warren and social-justice activists, it is unlikely that the Business Roundtable would have felt a need to appease.

headline: Audiobooks, Print Give Different Advantages
summary: While Mr. Austin sees correct prosody as a selling point for audiobooks, I see it as an intrusion on the spaces in my mind.

headline: Reward for Brave Wokeness
summary: Alert students, such as the New School genius who informed the authorities of his/her/its agony at hearing James Baldwin’s actual choice of words, should be rewarded for his/her/its bravery.

headline: Ex-Congressman Joe Walsh Begins Republican Campaign Against Trump
summary: Former U.S. Rep. Joe Walsh launched a long-shot Republican presidential campaign, casting President Trump as a failed leader.

headline: The Market Gets What It Wants
summary: Its recent drop is like a tantrum, screaming at President Trump to knock off the tariffs.

headline: What You Haven’t Read About Brazil
summary: The Amazon fires are mainly the result of drought, while Bolsonaro’s reforms are paving the way for faster growth.

headline: ‘Free Enterprise’ Review: A Motto for Capitalism
summary: Free enterprise was touted as “an old-fashioned verity” at odds with the New Deal’s vogue for public-sector programs.

headline: Don’t Hate Koch Because He Was Generous
summary: He didn’t demand his beneficiaries march in ideological lockstep. His detractors do.

headline: The Weaponization of History
summary: Ignorantly invoking slavery or the Holocaust is an affront to those who seriously study the past.

headline: Make Denmark Another Offer for Greenland
summary: The island is an important strategic location in a world that is realigning with unprecedented speed.

headline: Don’t Give Up on Biosimilars—Congress Can Give Them a Boost
summary: Drugs grown in live cells are hard to replicate. But policy changes can help accelerate the process.

headline: NotableQuotable: Climate Politics
summary: ‘Inslee’s lack of success does reveal a political problem for climate advocates.’

headline: Photos: Hong Kong Police and Protesters Engage in Violent Clashes
summary: In Hong Kong violence Sunday, some officers wield guns as protesters launch Molotov cocktails or bricks and fire slingshots.

headline: Andrew Luck Retired Early. Will Other Players Follow?
summary: Today’s NFL players are far more aware of the physical toll the game takes—an issue that can last well beyond their playing days.

headline: The Bond Market Is Wrong. Inflation Will Return, Someday.
summary: To believe inflation will stay very low for a very long time requires believing both that central banks are running on empty and that governments won’t offer fiscal help to counter a downturn. The first has a kernel of truth, but central bankers are not entirely out of gas.

headline: Over a Quarter of NYC Students Attend Private or Charter Schools
summary: How much children in New York City neighborhoods use the public-education system varies widely by their parents’ wealth, religious traditions and other factors, new data show.

headline: Getting Pulled by a Horse Can Actually Be Serious Exercise
summary: A D.C. lawyer spends several days a week harness racing, and puts in a lot of time in the boxing gym to prep for races.

headline: Americans Have Shifted Dramatically on What Values Matter Most
summary: The values that Americans say define the national character are changing, as younger generations rate patriotism, religion and having children as less important to them than did young people two decades ago, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News survey finds.

headline: Latest Stock Volatility Adds to August Turbulence
summary: Stocks enter the final week of the month coming off one of their rockiest stretches of 2019, the latest example of tariff-induced volatility that has some investors bracing for more fluctuation.

headline: The Wisdom of Andrew Luck’s Retirement
summary: The news of Andrew Luck’s decision to abruptly leave the NFL at age 29 may have shocked some, but the Colts quarterback did not seem tormented by his choice.

headline: Electric Vehicle Shift Will Keep a Lid on Oil Prices
summary: The world may be moving away from gas guzzlers quicker than planned. Oil prognosticators should take note.

headline: Diverging Paths of Stocks and Data Vex Investors
summary: Investors say they are finding it increasingly difficult to reconcile the sustained rise in share prices with widening cracks in the U.S. economy.

headline: New Details Emerge Over Mallinckrodt’s Role in Opioid Crisis
summary: More details and questions about Mallinckrodt’s role in the opioid crisis are emerging, including whether it effectively guarded against products leaving legal distribution channels.

headline: China’s Central Bank Unveils New Mortgage Loan Policy
summary: China’s central bank adjusted interest-rate mechanisms Sunday for the second time this month, this time focused on mortgage loans, in what it said was a bid to price them closer to market rates but also in ways that might avoid further inflating property prices.

headline: U.K.’s Johnson Charms Trump, Questions Trade War
summary: Boris Johnson has peppered Trump with calls as he seeks to shore up Britain’s ties with the U.S. On Sunday, he was rewarded with warm words and the promise of a quick trade deal with the U.S.

headline: After #MeToo, Films Face Test
summary: New movies from scrutinized directors show in theaters overseas, but maybe not in U.S.

headline: Netanyahu Reaches for the Russian Vote
summary: For years, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has largely ceded efforts to woo Russian-speaking immigrants to a rival who had helped him form coalition governments. Now, he sees Russian speakers as a key to his political survival.

headline: Hedge Funds Wager China’s HNA Will Look After Foreign Investors
summary: Hedge funds have made quick profits on debt tied to HNA Group, even as the airlines-to-hotels conglomerate has scaled back internationally and fallen behind on other obligations.

headline: As Bus Ridership Plummets in Los Angeles, Efforts to Boost It Hit Speed Bumps
summary: Bus ridership in America’s second-largest city is plummeting as more commuters use growing incomes from the healthy economy to buy a car. Transit officials are trying to change that.

headline: Deutsche Bank and UBS Explored European Banking Alliance
summary: Deutsche Bank and UBS had talks as recently as mid-June to form an unusual alliance of investment-banking operations, according to people familiar with the discussions.

headline: Water Cannons and a Gun Shot: Hong Kong Protest Violence Intensifies
summary: Hong Kong police deployed water cannons for the first time Sunday in a show of force as pro-democracy protests turned violent following nearly two weeks of relative calm.

headline: Tension Between Trump, World Leaders Takes Spotlight at G-7 Summit
summary: President Trump clashed with world leaders over the U.S. trade war with China and a host of foreign-policy issues at a Group of Seven summit that showed his isolation on the world stage.

headline: Israel Strikes Iranian Targets in Syria to Prevent ‘Killer Drone’ Attack
summary: Israel said it struck military facilities in Syria to prevent suspected planned attacks from Iranian forces, raising the risk of a clash with Tehran amid a broader Israeli campaign to counter the military activities of the Islamic Republic.

headline: Central Bankers Worry About Trump’s Tactics to Reorder Global Trade
summary: The world’s central bankers are increasingly worried that President Trump’s tactics to reorder global trade are destabilizing economies in ways that they can’t easily fix.

headline: Disney Enlists Superfans as It Prepares to Face Off Against Netflix
summary: Disney’s high-profile attempt to compete in streaming was center stage at D23, where a slew of new shows and movies for Disney+ was announced and fans were offered a three-year deal for the service at a deep discount.

headline: Hong Kong Protests Force Companies to Choose: Their Employees or China
summary: Employers early on supported their workers’ desire to protest but have started to shift under pressure from Beijing. “Every company in Hong Kong is in a delicate situation.”

headline: Trial of Ex-White House Counsel Reveals Maneuvering Behind Foreign Influence Campaign
summary: The criminal trial of a prominent lawyer has provided a behind-the-scenes, often unflattering look at how public-relations agents, political consultants and lawyers set about shaping public opinion for foreign governments.

headline: Trump Gambles That Trade War Will Pay Off in 2020
summary: President Trump’s trade battle with China is shaping up as a definitive issue in the 2020 campaign, with shaken financial markets and fears of an economic slowdown testing the Republican’s insistence that his blunt-force trade posture will be an asset.

headline: Latin America Hangs On to Its Economic Gloom
summary: The old joke about Brazil is that the South American giant is the country of the future and always will be, but the same might be said for Latin America as a whole.

headline: The New Pay Gap: What Firms Report Paying CEOs Versus What They Take Home
summary: Big companies tend to pay their chief executives big bucks. Less widely known: Many of those CEOs wind up receiving much more, often well after the compensation is initially disclosed.

headline: Billie Eilish Has a Brother Named Finneas. He’s Ready to Headline.
summary: An understated contributor to the success of his superstar sister aims for his own turn in the spotlight.
